sentences.sentence: Beginning today, the Australia's China Challenge series of reporting, analysis and opinion will discuss how Australia should deal with the increased security risks to its export-based prosperity from China's increasing assertiveness under Xi Jinping, China's President since 2013.
Most of Australia's political leaders, business chiefs and foreign policy boffins took what now appears to be an overly optimistic, even unrealistic, view of China's progress.
They assumed that, as China grew bigger and richer, it would politically liberalise as it converged with the West like its North East Asian neighbours.

Tony Abbott's offhand declaration that Xi Jinping's speech to the Australian parliament in 2014 included some commitment to democracy was perhaps the highpoint of Australian naivety - or miscalculation.Australia was at the forefront of bringing China out of the Cold War deep freeze when opposition leader Gough Whitlam went to Beijing in 1971, a year before US president Richard Nixon in 1972.
Australia profited from Deng Xiaoping's reforms of 1978, which liberalised the Chinese economy.
The Red Menace to Australia's far north has been transformed into the major source of Australia's modern prosperity.
Despite the rising geopolitical tensions and a deteriorating bilateral relationship, the importance of Australia's economic engagement with China has been underlined amid the pandemic shock.
In June, China's share of Australian goods exports hit a new record high of 48 per cent as Australian iron ore fires up China's post-virus recovery.
Australia has continued to prosper by supplying raw materials to fuel the biggest industrialisation the world has known.

Australia's post-war economic development is based on the opportunities for trade between Australia's resource-based economy and the populous nations of North East Asia, starting with the 1957 commerce agreement between Japan and the Menzies government and peaking with the 2014 "comprehensive strategic partnership" between the Abbott government and the world's 21st-century manufacturing powerhouse.Clearly the widely held optimism that Australia would only gain from China's mercantilist expansion are now dashed, even as Australia's hard-to-replace iron ore trade booms.
Australia must instead face up to the geopolitical challenges posed by being a frontline state in authoritarian China's rise to strategic power in the Indo-Pacific neighbourhood.

Beijing's strategically assertive military and diplomatic aggression and ambition to be a regional superpower makes it much more difficult to balance Australia's China-prosperity with national security.Managing China, as Scott Morrison told political editor Phillip Coorey in today's exclusive interview, now calls for "strategic patience and consistency".
Mr Morrison rightly says Australia's trade relationship with China is mutually beneficial.
Australia has therefore never sought Cold War-style containment of China's peaceful rise and prosperity inside a rules-based global order.
Hence, Mr Morrison does not back the Trump administration's aggressive great power rival posturing and regime-change rhetoric.

Instead, Mr Morrison says Australia aims to avoid confrontation while being "very clear about our positions on things and our national interests".Thus Australia will not bow to China's wolf warrior trade reprisals.
But this also means deepening the alliance with our traditional security partner to encourage America to remain engaged in maintaining the region's strategic balance.
Australia must also build the regional alliances with Indo-Pacific nations that can encourage Beijing to play by the rules of the international system.

For, as Mr Morrison says, the next stage of Australia's management of China's rise is not about ideology or conflict but the "alignment" of regional powers to build the collective stability and security that is now needed to guarantee the independent sovereignty of every nation.
Applying the Morrison doctrine to Australia's China challenge could deeply test this high-income nation at the foot of Asia.
Just as exporters must ensure their paperwork is in order, China must not be given pretext for being aggrieved by not being consulted first on legitimate initiatives such as the COVID-19 inquiry.
Australia's prosperity and security over the next few decades is at stake.

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly uncertain about this document. The writing style and content are not particularly AI-like.
documents.inputText: Beginning today, the Australia's China Challenge series of reporting, analysis and opinion will discuss how Australia should deal with the increased security risks to its export-based prosperity from China's increasing assertiveness under Xi Jinping, China's President since 2013. Most of Australia's political leaders, business chiefs and foreign policy boffins took what now appears to be an overly optimistic, even unrealistic, view of China's progress. They assumed that, as China grew bigger and richer, it would politically liberalise as it converged with the West like its North East Asian neighbours. Tony Abbott's offhand declaration that Xi Jinping's speech to the Australian parliament in 2014 included some commitment to democracy was perhaps the highpoint of Australian naivety - or miscalculation.Australia was at the forefront of bringing China out of the Cold War deep freeze when opposition leader Gough Whitlam went to Beijing in 1971, a year before US president Richard Nixon in 1972. Australia profited from Deng Xiaoping's reforms of 1978, which liberalised the Chinese economy. The Red Menace to Australia's far north has been transformed into the major source of Australia's modern prosperity. Despite the rising geopolitical tensions and a deteriorating bilateral relationship, the importance of Australia's economic engagement with China has been underlined amid the pandemic shock. In June, China's share of Australian goods exports hit a new record high of 48 per cent as Australian iron ore fires up China's post-virus recovery. Australia has continued to prosper by supplying raw materials to fuel the biggest industrialisation the world has known. Australia's post-war economic development is based on the opportunities for trade between Australia's resource-based economy and the populous nations of North East Asia, starting with the 1957 commerce agreement between Japan and the Menzies government and peaking with the 2014 "comprehensive strategic partnership" between the Abbott government and the world's 21st-century manufacturing powerhouse.Clearly the widely held optimism that Australia would only gain from China's mercantilist expansion are now dashed, even as Australia's hard-to-replace iron ore trade booms. Australia must instead face up to the geopolitical challenges posed by being a frontline state in authoritarian China's rise to strategic power in the Indo-Pacific neighbourhood. Beijing's strategically assertive military and diplomatic aggression and ambition to be a regional superpower makes it much more difficult to balance Australia's China-prosperity with national security.Managing China, as Scott Morrison told political editor Phillip Coorey in today's exclusive interview, now calls for "strategic patience and consistency". Mr Morrison rightly says Australia's trade relationship with China is mutually beneficial. Australia has therefore never sought Cold War-style containment of China's peaceful rise and prosperity inside a rules-based global order. Hence, Mr Morrison does not back the Trump administration's aggressive great power rival posturing and regime-change rhetoric. Instead, Mr Morrison says Australia aims to avoid confrontation while being "very clear about our positions on things and our national interests".Thus Australia will not bow to China's wolf warrior trade reprisals. But this also means deepening the alliance with our traditional security partner to encourage America to remain engaged in maintaining the region's strategic balance. Australia must also build the regional alliances with Indo-Pacific nations that can encourage Beijing to play by the rules of the international system. For, as Mr Morrison says, the next stage of Australia's management of China's rise is not about ideology or conflict but the "alignment" of regional powers to build the collective stability and security that is now needed to guarantee the independent sovereignty of every nation. Applying the Morrison doctrine to Australia's China challenge could deeply test this high-income nation at the foot of Asia. Just as exporters must ensure their paperwork is in order, China must not be given pretext for being aggrieved by not being consulted first on legitimate initiatives such as the COVID-19 inquiry. Australia's prosperity and security over the next few decades is at stake.
